title: Taia Storrs
text:
Water Resources | Sustainability | GIS
Graduate student passionate about sustainable water solutions for the Western United States.
About Me Projects Gallery

title: Taia Storrs
text:
I recently graduated from Colorado State University with a Bachelor of Science in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability, completing my degree in three years with a minor in Watershed Science. This fall, I began pursuing a Professional Science Master’s in Water Resources through CSU’s Accelerated Master’s Program in ESS.
My academic and professional interests center on sustainable water solutions for addressing water scarcity in the Western United States. Through my coursework and field experience, I’ve developed a strong passion for water resource management and environmental sustainability. I’m excited to continue building the technical, interdisciplinary, and collaborative skills needed to contribute to resilient water systems in the face of climate change.
I am dedicated to creating sustainable improvements in the water sector, with the aim of contributing my expertise to sustainable water management within urban settings.

title: Taia Storrs
text:
Skills & Proficiencies

Technical Tools: ArcGIS, R, Microsoft Office Suite
Data Analysis: Field data collection, dataset cleaning, and statistical analysis in R and Excel
Communication: Stakeholder communication and report delivery

title: Projects
text:
Colorado State University | Spring 2025
Collaborated with stakeholder CitSci to design systems for CSU’s upcoming Center for Participatory Science:

Wrote a background paper highlighting barriers and strategies for inclusive research
Built a participant database using Airtable and Fillout
Implemented communication systems via Teams, Outlook/Gmail, and Calendly




Spring 2024
Conducted statistical analyses in RStudio to quantify correlations between sea ice extent and global sea level rise:

Merged and cleaned satellite-derived datasets
Ran correlation tests (Pearson’s r = -0.48) and visualized spatial/temporal trends
Presented findings demonstrating a significant negative correlation between polar ice melt and global sea level rise




Fall 2023

Applied ArcGIS to integrate hydrology and transportation datasets
Created a map of Longs Peak’s hydrography and road networks to demonstrate spatial data visualization skills

title: Projects
text:
Field Experience

Natural Resource Ecology & Measurement
Colorado State University – Mountain Campus | Summer 2024

Identified 120 different plant and animal species of Northern Colorado Region
Assessed mountain shrub, ponderosa pine/aspen, lodgepole pine, spruce-fir, and alpine ecosystems
Collected recreation, watershed, range, wildlife, and forestry data using quadrants, line-intercepts, transects, and point-centered quarters
Generated written reports for each ecosystem assessed



Limnology Field Work
Colorado State University | Fall 2024

Collected depth profiles: temperature, DO content, pH, water chemistry, and algae/zooplankton sampling
Utilized Van Dorn bottles, Sonde, and macroinvertebrate nets for sampling



Snow Hydrology Field Work
Colorado State University | Fall 2024

Collected snowpack data at Cameron Pass via core samples
Analyzed Joe Wright SNOTEL station data

title: Projects
text:
Technical Coursework

R Programming & Geospatial Analysis
Introduction to R Programming (Summer 2024) - Organized, cleaned, and analyzed datasets - Generated reproducible visualizations and statistical summaries
Introduction to Geospatial Science (Fall 2023) - Managed and interpreted spatial datasets using ArcGIS - Applied spatial analysis to environmental challenges


Hydrology & Water Resources
Land Use Hydrology (Fall 2024) - Modeled streamflow, soil moisture, evapotranspiration, and other hydrologic processes - Addressed water resource challenges
Land Use and Water Quality (Spring 2025) - Investigated impacts of land management practices on surface/groundwater quality
Water Resource Development (Spring 2025) - Evaluated water infrastructure planning approaches - Assessed economic, environmental, and social trade-offs
Water Law for Non-Lawyers (Fall 2024) - Studied Western water law doctrines (prior appropriation and riparian rights) - Analyzed water allocation case studies

title: Gallery
text:
Longs Peak Hydrography and Road Networks


GIS analysis integrating hydrology and transportation datasets.



Burned Area


Assessed and collected data from a burned area at CSU’s Mountain Campus



Roberts Tunnel Outlet


Assessed Roberts Tunnel Outlet



Streamflow


Collected watershed data and measurements using a headrod at the Mountain Campus

More photos and projects coming soon!
